title: Utility & Internet Costs in Anguilla
content:
The cost of utilities and internet in Anguilla can vary depending on the size of the apartment and the service provider, with a typical monthly utility bill for an 85 sqm apartment ranging from $200 to $400 USD.

[SECTION] Utility Costs Overview [/SECTION]
The utility infrastructure in Anguilla is relatively well-developed, with most homes having access to electricity, water, and gas. However, the costs of these utilities can fluctuate depending on the season, with prices tend to be higher during the peak tourist season from December to April. The Anguilla Electricity Company Ltd. is the sole provider of electricity on the island, and the cost of electricity is around $0.35 per kWh. Water is provided by the Anguilla Water Corporation, and the cost is around $10 per 1,000 gallons.

The overall quality of the utility infrastructure in Anguilla is good, with most homes having access to modern amenities. However, there can be occasional power outages and water shortages, especially during periods of high demand. It's also worth noting that the cost of utilities can vary depending on the location, with apartments in the capital city of The Valley tend to be more expensive than those in other parts of the island. Additionally, some apartments may have additional costs such as garbage collection and municipal fees, which can range from $20 to $50 per month.

[SECTION] Utility Tips [/SECTION]
- To set up utilities in Anguilla, you will typically need to provide proof of address and identification, and pay a deposit, which can range from $50 to $200.
- Prepaid electricity plans can be a good option for those who want to avoid surprise bills, but postpaid plans may offer more flexibility and convenience.
- The best internet providers in Anguilla are Digicel and Flow, which offer a range of plans and speeds to suit different needs and budgets.
- To save on utility bills, consider using energy-efficient appliances, turning off lights and electronics when not in use, and using a water filter instead of bottled water.
- It's also a good idea to negotiate with your landlord or service provider to see if you can get a better deal on your utilities, especially if you are renting a long-term apartment.
